docs.lead_paragraph: As New Hampshire voters began to cast ballots on Tuesday, the Republican candidates sought to slow Mitt Romney’s march to the nomination, branding him as a corporate villain.

headline.seo: Voting in N.H. Opens as Romney Fends Off Attacks
headline.main: Voting in N.H. Opens as Romney Fends Off Attacks
headline.print_headline: On Primary Eve, Rivals Try to Put Romney on Defensive

docs.abstract: Republican candidates campaigning in New Hampshire seek to slow Mitt Romney’s front-runner status and raise doubts about his electability by branding him as a job-killing corporate villain; attacks are so piercing that some leading Republicans urge the candidates to back off.
docs.snippet: As New Hampshire voters began to cast ballots on Tuesday, the Republican candidates sought to slow Mitt Romney’s march to the nomination, branding him as a corporate villain.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Michael Barbaro and Trip Gabriel in Manchester, N.H.; Richard A. Oppel Jr. in Anderson, S.C.; Ashley Parker in Hudson, N.H.; and Katharine Q. Seelye in Somersworth, N.H.
byline.original: By JEFF ZELENY and JIM RUTENBERG

docs.lead_paragraph: The economic downturn reined in the growth of health spending as many people lost jobs, income and health insurance, the government said in a report.

headline.seo: Health Spending Held Down by Recession

docs.abstract: Obama administration report published in the journal Health Affairs shows that the recession in 2007-2009 reined in the growth of health spending as many people lost jobs, income and health insurance; graph highlights rates of national spending on health in 2010.
docs.snippet: The economic downturn reined in the growth of health spending as many people lost jobs, income and health insurance, the government said in a report.

headline.main: More Health Clinics Pop Up Inside Retailers

docs.abstract: The number of medical clinics inside retail stores is expected to boom, in part because of incentives under the new federal health care law. Chains like Safeway and Walmart already have big expansion plans.
docs.snippet: The number of medical clinics inside retail stores is expected to boom, in part because of incentives under the new federal health care law. Chains like Safeway and Walmart already have big expansion plans.

docs.lead_paragraph: The growth of health clinics inside retail stores rebounded in 2011 and is poised for a "second spring" this year, driven by well-capitalized retailers and grocers, according to a new report.

headline.main: Economic Toll of Diabetes Begins Early

docs.abstract: Diabetes may be more than a hazard to health. A new study shows that young adults with the disease have lower lifetime earnings and fewer job prospects than their peers.
docs.snippet: Diabetes may be more than a hazard to health. A new study shows that young adults with the disease have lower lifetime earnings and fewer job prospects than their peers.

headline.main: NYT Districts API helps Fractured Atlas help artists

docs.abstract: The arts, and the benefits to the public they provide, sometimes gets lost, barely noticed by government. Fractured Atlas, a New York City-based multi-disciplinary arts service organization, is finding that by creating information and data services for its members and for city arts communities, it can also provide more effective advocacy for the arts to government. Fractured Atlas uses the New York Times' District API to create and run these services and to link them to its arts advocacy mission.
